action: I want to review audit logs to track user operation history and permission change history
reason: To detect signs of fraudulent operations or information leakage and maintain internal control
acceptance_criteria: Audit logs are only viewable by authenticated users.
Viewing permissions are restricted to the Audit role.
All important operations (Create/Update/Delete/Login/Permission changes) are subject to recording.
Logs include user_id, operation details, target ID, and timestamp.
Logs are automatically generated and cannot be manually edited.
Logs are stored in tamper-evident storage.
The log retention period is configurable.
Log deletion is possible only by administrators.
Deletion operations are also recorded in the audit log.
A log search function exists.
Search criteria can be filtered by period, user, and operation type.
A log export function exists (CSV/Excel).
Formula injection countermeasures are implemented for CSV output.
Logs are stored in encrypted storage.
Communication is conducted via HTTPS.
SQL injection countermeasures are implemented.
Log content is protected against XSS.
The API is REST-compliant.
API versioning is managed.
Rate limiting is applied to the API.
Internal system information is not included in the API response.
Error logs are stored upon log generation failure.
Log generation processing is managed via an asynchronous queue.
Automatic retry is performed upon queue processing failure.
Permission change history is stored in a separate table.
Roles before and after the change are recorded in the permission change history.
Access logs for viewing audit logs are also recorded.
Log access history includes the viewer's ID.
Target response time is within 500ms (excluding searches).
Pagination is applied when searching large volumes of logs.
Log events subject to SLA monitoring can be configured.
SLA violations are integrated with the alert notification function.
An audit report generation function exists.
Report generation history is stored.
API authorization checks are implemented on the server side.
Unauthorized access attempts are recorded in the logs immediately.
Audit logs are subject to backup.
Error logs are recorded upon backup failure.
